'A' leads letters
thirukuralapi.trans2: the Ancient Lord Leads and lords the entire world

thirukuralapi.trans: The sea of births they alone swim Who clench His feet and cleave to Him
Leaving ripe fruits the raw he eats Who speaks harsh words when sweet word suits
The wealth heaped by the churlish base Is pure milk soured by impure vase
Dead is he with wealth in pile Unenjoyed, it is futile
The niggard miser thinks wealth is all He hoards, gives not is born devil
A burden he is to earth indeed Who hoards without a worthy deed
What legacy can he leave behind Who is for approach too unkind
What is the good of crores they hoard To give and enjoy whose heart is hard
Great wealth unused for oneself nor To worthy men is but a slur
Who loaths to help have-nots, his gold Is like a spinster-belle grown old
The idle wealth of unsought men Is poison-fruit-tree amidst a town
Others usurp the shining gold In loveless, stingy, vicious hold
Unhelped in turn good help given Exceeds in worth earth and heaven
The brief want of the rich benign Is like rainclouds growing thin
To shrink from evil deed is shame The rest is blush of fair-faced dame
Food, dress and such are one for all Modesty marks the higher soul
All lives have their lodge in flesh Perfection has its home in blush
Shame is the jewel of dignity Shameless swagger is vanity
In them resides the sense of shame Who blush for their and other's blame
The great refuse the wonder-world Without modesty's hedge and shield
For shame their life the shame-sensed give Loss of shame they won't outlive
Virtue is much ashamed of him Who shameless does what others shame
Lapse in manners injures the race Want of shame harms every good grace
A help rendered in hour of need Though small is greater than the world
Movements of the shameless in heart Are string-led puppet show in fact
No greatness is grander like Saying "
These two exalt a noble home Ardent effort and ripe wisdom
When one resolves to raise his race Loin girt up God leads his ways
Who raise their races with ceaseless pain No need for plan
thirukuralapi.trans2: their ends will gain

thirukuralapi.trans: Who keeps his house without a blame People around, his kinship claim
Who raise their race which gave them birth Are deemed as men of manly worth
Like dauntless heroes in battle field The home-burden rests on the bold
No season have they who raise their race Sloth and pride will honour efface
Is not his frame a vase for woes Who from mishaps shields his house?
Help rendered without weighing fruits Outweighs the sea in grand effects
A house will fall by a mishap With no good man to prop it up
Farming though hard is foremost trade Men ply at will but ploughmen lead
Tillers are linch-pin of mankind Bearing the rest who cannot tend
They live who live to plough and eat The rest behind them bow and eat
Who have the shade of cornful crest Under their umbra umbrellas rest
Who till and eat, beg not; nought hide But give to those who are in need
Should ploughmen sit folding their hands Desire-free monks too suffer wants
Moulds dried to quarter-dust ensure Rich crops without handful manure
Better manure than plough; then weed; Than irrigating, better guard
If landsmen sit sans moving about The field like wife will sulk and pout
Help given though millet-small Knowers count its good palm-tree tall
Fair good earth will laugh to see Idlers pleading poverty
What gives more pain than scarcity? No pain pinches like poverty
The sinner Want is enemy dire Of joys of earth and heaven there
The craving itch of poverty Kills graceful words and ancestry
Want makes even good familymen Utter words that are low and mean
The pest of wanton poverty Brings a train of misery
The poor men's words are thrown away Though from heart good things they say
Even the mother looks as stranger The poor devoid of character
The killing Want of yesterday Will it pester me even to-day?
One may sleep in the midst of fire In want a wink of sleep is rare
A help is not the help's measure It is gainer's worth and pleasure
Renounce their lives the poor must Or salt and gruel go to waste
Demand from those who can supply Default is theirs when they deny
Even demand becomes a joy When the things comes without annoy
Request has charm form open hearts Who know the duty on their part
Like giving even asking seems From those who hide not even in dreams
The needy demand for help because The world has men who don't refuse
The pain of poverty shall die Before the free who don't deny
When givers without scorn impart A thrill of delight fills the heart
This grand cool world shall move to and fro Sans Askers like a puppet show
Where stands the glory of givers Without obligation seekers?
Forget not friendship of the pure Forsake not timely helpers sure
The needy should not scowl at "
Not to beg is billions worth E'en from eye-like friends who give with mirth
Let World-Maker loiter and rot If "
Nothing is hard like hard saying "
All space is small before the great Who beg not e'en in want acute
Though gruel thin, nothing is sweet Like the food earned by labour's sweat
It may be water for the cow Begging tongue is mean anyhow
If beg they must I beg beggers Not to beg from shrinking misers
The hapless bark of beggary splits On the rock of refusing hits
The heart at thought of beggars melts
thirukuralapi.trans2: It dies at repulsing insults

thirukuralapi.trans: Through sevenfold births, in memory fares The willing friend who wiped one's tears
The word "
The mean seem men only in form We have never seen such a sham
The base seem richer than the good For no care enters their heart or head
The base are like gods
thirukuralapi.trans2: for they too As prompted by their desire do

thirukuralapi.trans: When the base meets a rake so vile Him he will exceed, exult and smile
Fear forms the conduct of the low Craving avails a bit below
The base are like the beaten drum Since other's secrets they proclaim
The base their damp hand will not shake But for fists clenched their jaws to break
The good by soft words profits yield The cane-like base when crushed and killed
Faults in others the mean will guess On seeing how they eat and dress
To forget good turns is not good Good it is over wrong not to brood
The base hasten to sell themselves From doom to flit and nothing else
Is it an angel? A fair peacock Or jewelled belle? To my mind a shock!
The counter glances of this belle Are armied dart of the Love-Angel
Not known before -I spy Demise In woman's guise with battling eyes
This artless dame has darting eyes That drink the life of men who gaze
Is it death, eye or doe? All three In winsome woman's look I see
If cruel brows unbent, would screen Her eyes won't cause me trembling pain
Vest on the buxom breast of her Looks like rutting tusker's eye-cover
Ah these fair brows shatter my might Feared by foemen yet to meet
Which jewel can add to her beauty With fawn-like looks and modesty?
Let deadly harms be forgotten While remembering one good-turn
To the drunk alone is wine delight Nothing delights like love at sight
Her painted eyes, two glances dart One hurts; the other heals my heart
Her furtive lightning glance is more Than enjoyment of sexual lore
She looked
thirukuralapi.trans2: looking bowed her head And love-plant was with water fed

thirukuralapi.trans: I look
thirukuralapi.trans2: she droops to earth awhile I turn

thirukuralapi.trans: No direct gaze
thirukuralapi.trans2: a side-long glance She darts at me and smiles askance

thirukuralapi.trans: Their words at first seem an offence But quick we feel them friendly ones
Harsh little words; offended looks, Are feigned consenting love-lorn tricks
What a grace the slim maid has! As I look she slightly smiles
Between lovers we do discern A stranger's look of unconcern
The genial rain ambrosia call: The world but lasts while rain shall fall
The virtue-killer may be saved Not benefit-killer who is damned
The words of mouth are of no use When eye to eye agrees the gaze
In this bangled beauty dwell The joys of sight sound touch taste smell
The cure for ailment is somewhere For fair maid's ill she is the cure
Is lotus-eyed lord's heaven so sweet As sleep in lover's arms so soft?
Away it burns and cools anear Wherefrom did she get this fire?
The arms of my flower-tressed maid Whatever I wish that that accord
My simple maid has nectar arms Each embrace brings life-thrilling charms
Ah the embrace of this fair dame Is like sharing one's food at home
Joy is the fast embrace that doth Not admit e'en air between both
Sulking, feeling and clasping fast These three are sweets of lover's tryst
Equity is supreme virtue It is to give each man his due
As knowledge reveals past ignorance So is the belle as love gets close
Soft blessed anicha flower, hail On whom I dote is softer still
You can't liken flowers by many eyed, To her bright eyes, O mind dismayed
The bamboo-shouldered has pearl-like smiles Fragrant breath and lance-like eyes
Lily droops down to ground and says I can't equal the jewelled-one's eyes
Anicha flower with stem she wears To her breaking waist sad-drum-blares!
Stars are confused to know which is The moon and which is woman's face
Are there spots on the lady's face Just as in moon that changes phase?
Like my lady's face if you shine All my love to you
thirukuralapi.trans2: hail O moon!

thirukuralapi.trans: Like the face of my flower-eyed one If you look, then shine alone O moon!
Wealth of the man of equity Grows and lasts to posterity
The soft flower and the swan's down are Like nettles to the feet of the fair
Like milk and honey the dew is sweet From her white teeth whose word is soft
Love between me and this lady Is like bond between soul and body
Depart image in my pupil Giving room to my fair-browed belle!
Life with my jewel is existence Death it is her severance
Can I forget? I recall always The charms of her bright battling eyes
So subtle is my lover's form Ever in my eyes winking, no harm
My lover in my eyes abides I paint them not lest he hides
My lover abides in my heart I fear hot food lest he feels hot
My eyes wink not lest he should hide And him as cruel the townsmen chide
Though profitable, turn away From unjust gains without delay
He abides happy in my heart But people mistake he is apart

Pangs of passion find no recourse Except riding *`palmyra horse' * Palmyra horse or 'Madal' is a torture expressive of the burning passion of the lover to the beloved The lover's body is laid on a rough pricking palmyra bed and he is carried along the street with songs of love pangs The parents of the lovers first reproach them and then consent to their marriage
Pining body and mind lose shame And take to riding of the palm
Once I was modest and manly My love has now Madal only
Rushing flood of love sweeps away The raft of shame and firmness, aye!
Palm-ride and pangs of eventide Are gifts of wreath-like bracelet maid
Madal I ride at midnight for My eyes sleep not seeing this fair
Her sea-like lust seeks not Madal! Serene is woman's self control
Lust betrays itself in haste Though women are highly soft and chaste
My perplexed love roves public street Believing that none knows its secret
The worthy and the unworthy Are seen in their posterity
Fools laugh at me before my eyes For they feel not my pangs and sighs
Rumour sustains my existence Good luck! many know not its sense
Rumour gives me the flower-like belle People know not what rare angel
I profit by this public rumour Having not, I feel, I have her
Rumour inflames the love I seek Or else it becomes bleak and weak
Drink delights as liquor flows Love delights as rumour grows
One lasting day we met alone Lasting rumours eclipse our moon
Scandal manures
thirukuralapi.trans2: mother's refrain Waters the growth of this love-pain

thirukuralapi.trans: To quench the lust by rumour free Is to quench fire by pouring ghee
Who said "
Loss and gain by cause arise
thirukuralapi.trans2: Equal mind adorns the wise

thirukuralapi.trans: Town raising this cry, I desire Consent is easy from my sire
Tell me if you but do not leave, Your quick return to those who live
His sight itself was pleasing, near Embrace pains now by partings fear
On whom shall I lay my trust hence While parting lurks in knowing ones?
He parts whose love told me -fear not Is my trust in him at default?
Stop his parting -my life to save Meeting is rare if he would leave
His hardness says, "
Will not my gliding bangles' cry The parting of my lord betray?
Bitter is life in friendless place
thirukuralapi.trans2: Worse is parting love's embrace!

thirukuralapi.trans: Can fire that burns by touch burn like Parting of the hearts love-sick?
Of perdition let him be sure Who leaves justice to sinful lure
Many survive pangs of parting Not I this sore so distressing
It swells out like baled out spring How to bear this pain so writhing?
I can't conceal this nor complain For shame to him who caused this pain
In life -poles of this wearied frame Are poised the weights of lust and shame
My lust is a sea
thirukuralapi.trans2: I do not see A raft to go across safely

thirukuralapi.trans: What wilt they prove when they are foes Who in friendship bring me woes!
The pleasure in love is oceanful But its pangs are more painful
Wild waves of love I swim shoreless Pining alone in midnight hush
Night's mercy lulls all souls to sleep Keeping but me for companionship
Crueller than that cruel he Are midnight hours gliding slowly
The just reduced to poverty Is not held down by equity
Like heart, if my sight reaches him It won't in floods of tears swim!
The eye pointed him to me
thirukuralapi.trans2: why then They weep with malady and pine?

thirukuralapi.trans: Why should these dyed eyes grieve now sans Regrets for their thoughtless glance?
Eyes darted eager glance that day It's funny that they weep today
These eyes left me to endless grief Crying adry without relief
My eyes causing lust more than sea Suffer that torture sleeplessly
Lo! eyes that wrought this love-sickness Are victims of the same themselves
Let tears dry up pining pining In eyes that eyed him longing longing
Ther's he whose lips loved, not his heart Yet my eyes pine seeing him not
He comes
thirukuralapi.trans2: no sleep

thirukuralapi.trans: Like balance holding equal scales A well poised mind is jewel of the wise
Like drum beats eyes declare my heart
thirukuralapi.trans2: From people who could hide his secret?

thirukuralapi.trans: My lover's parting, I allowed Whom to complain my hue pallid?
Claiming it is begot through him Pallor creeps and rides over my frame
He seized my beauty and modesty Leaving pangs and Pallor to me
He is my thought, his praise my theme Yet this pallor steals over my frame
My lover departed me there And pallor usurped my body here
Just as darkness waits for light-off Pallor looks for lover's arms-off
From his embrace I turned a nonce This pallor swallowed me at once
On my pallor they cast a slur But none says "
Let all my body become pale If he who took my leave fares well
Justice is upright, unbending And free from crooked word-twisting
Let people call me all pallid But my lover let them not deride
Stoneless fruit of love they have Who are beloved by those they love
The lover-and-beloved's self-givings Are like rains to living beings
The pride of living is for those Whose love is returned by love so close
Whose love is void of love in turn Are luckless with all esteems they earn
What can our lover do us now If he does not requite our love?
One sided pains
thirukuralapi.trans2: love in both souls Poises well like shoulder poles

thirukuralapi.trans: This cupid aims at me alone
thirukuralapi.trans2: Knows he not my pallor and pain?

thirukuralapi.trans: None is so firm as she who loves Without kind words from whom she dotes
The lover accords not my desires And yet his words sweeten my ears
The rain begets the food we eat
A trader's trade prospers fairly When his dealings are neighbourly
You tell your grief to listless he Bless my heart! rather fill up sea!
Love is sweeter than wine
thirukuralapi.trans2: for vast Is its delight at very thought

thirukuralapi.trans: Pains are off at the lover's thought In all aspects this love is sweet
To sneeze I tried hence but could not Me he tried to think but did not
Have I a place within his heart? Ah from mine he will never depart
Shame! My heart often he enters Banning me entry into his
Beyond the thought of life with him What else of life can I presume?
What will happen if I forget When his memory burns my heart?
I bring him to ceaseless memory He chides not
thirukuralapi.trans2: and thus honours me

thirukuralapi.trans: Dear life ebbs away by thought Of him who said we are one heart
Self-rule leads to realms of gods Indulgence leads to gloomy hades
Hail moon! Set not so that I find Him who left me but not my mind
How shall I feast this dream-vision That brings the beloved's love-mission?
I beg these fish-like dark eyes sleep To tell my lover how life I keep
In wakeful hours who sees me not I meet in dreams and linger yet
In dreams I enjoy his love-bliss Who in wakeful hours I miss
Dream-sight of him delights at once Awake-What of seeing him -hence
If wakeful hours come to nought My lov'r in dreams would nev'r depart
Awake he throws my overtures Adream, ah cruel! he tortures!
Asleep he embraces me fast
thirukuralapi.trans2: Awake he enters quick my heart

thirukuralapi.trans: In dreams who don't discern lovers Rue their missing in wakeful hours
No gains with self-control measure Guard with care this great treasure
The townsmen say he left me thus In dreams failing to see him close
Bless you! you are not eventide But killing dart to wedded bride!
Hail sad eventide dim and grim Has your mate like mine, cruel whim!
Wet eve came pale and trembling then Now it makes bold with growing pain
Lover away, comes eventide Like slayer to field of homicide
What good have I done to morning And what evil to this evening?
Evening pangs I have not known When my lord nev'r left me alone
Budding at dawn burgeoning all day This disease blooms in evening gay
A deadly arm, this shepherd's flute Hails flaming eve and slays my heart
Deluding eve if it prolongs The whole town will suffer love-pangs
Knowing wisdom who lives controlled Name and fame seek him untold
Thinking of him whose quest is wealth My life outlives the twilight stealth
To lift from want he left me afar His thought makes my eyes blush the flower
My pale tearful eyes betray The hardness of my husband, away
These arms that swelled on nuptial day Now shrunk proclaim "
Bracelets slip off the arms that have Lost old beauty for He took leave
Bereft of bracelets and old beauty Arms tell the cruel's cruelty
Arms thin, armlets loose make you call My sire cruel; that pains my soul
Go and tell the cruel, O mind Bruit ov'r my arms and glory find
The front of this fair one O paled As my clasping arms loosed their hold
Cool breeze crept between our embrace Her large rain-cloud-eyes paled at once
Firmly fixed in self serene The sage looks grander than mountain
Pale eyes pained seeing the pallor Of the bright forehead of this fair
Think of, O heart, some remedy To cure this chronic malady
Bless O mind! you pine in vain For me he has no love serene
O mind, why pine and sit moody? Who made you so pale lacks pity
Take these eyes and meet him, O heart Or their hunger will eat me out
He spurns our love and yet, O mind, Can we desert him as unkind?
Wrath is false, O heart, face-to face Sans huff, you rush to his sweet embrace
Off with love O mind, or shame I cannot endure both of them
Without pity he would depart! You sigh and seek his favour, poor heart!
The lover lives in Self you know; Whom you think, mind to whom you go?
Humility is good for all To the rich it adds a wealth special
Without a thought he deserted us To think of him will make us worse
Passion's axe shall break the door Of reserve bolted with my honour
The thing called lust is a heartless power It sways my mind at midnight hour
How to hide this lust which shows Itself while I sneeze unawares!
I was proud of my sex-reserve Lo lust betrays what I preserve
Dignity seeks not a deserter But Love-sick is its innovator
O Grief, my deserter you seek Of your caprice what shall I speak!
When lover's love does what it desires We forget all shame unawares
The cheater of many wily arts His tempting words break through women's hearts
In huff I went and felt at ease Heat to heart in sweet embrace
Who senses five like tortoise hold Their joy prolongs to births sevenfold
To feign dislike is it not rare For mates who melt like fat in fire?
My eyes are dim lustre-bereft Worn fingers count days since he left
Beauty pales and my bracelets slide; Why not forget him now, bright maid?
Will as guide he went to win Yet I live-to see him again
My heart in rapture heaves to see His retun with love to embrace me
Let me but gaze and gaze my spouse sallow on my soft shoulders files
Let my spouse return just a day Joy-drink shall drive my pain away
If my eye-like lord returneth Shall I sulk or clasp or do both?
May the king fight and win and give And with my wife I will feast this eve!
One day seems as seven to those Who yearn return of distant spouse
Rein the tongue if nothing else Or slips of tongue bring all the woes
When her heart is broken, what is The good of meeting and love-embrace?
You hide; but your painted eyes Restraint off, report your surmise
With seemly grace and stem-like arms The simple she has ample charms
Something shines through her jewelled charm Like thread shining through wreathed gem
Like scent in bud secrets conceal In the bosom of her half smile
The close-bangled belle's hidden thought Has a cure for my troubled heart She to Her Maid
His over-kind close embrace sooths; But makes me feel, loveless, he parts
Quick, my bracelets read before The mind of my lord of cool shore
My lover parted but yesterday
thirukuralapi.trans2: With sallowness it is seventh day The Maid Tells Him

thirukuralapi.trans: She views her armlets, her tender arms And then her feet; these are her norms
Even a single evil word Will turn all good results to bad
To express love-pangs by eyes and pray Is womanhood's womanly way
Rapture at thought and joy when seen Belong to love and not to wine
When passion grows palmyra-tall Sulking is wrong though millet-small
Though slighting me he acts his will My restless eyes would see him still
Huff I would, maid, but I forget; And leap to embrace him direct
When close I see not lord's blemish Like eyes that see not painter's brush
When he's with me I see not fault And nought but fault when he is not
To leap in stream which carries off When lord is close to feign a huff
Like wine to addicts that does disgrace Your breast, O thief, is for my embrace!
Flower-soft is love
thirukuralapi.trans2: a few alone Know its delicacy so fine

thirukuralapi.trans: The fire-burnt wounds do find a cure Tongue-burnt wound rests a running sore
She feigned dislike awhile but flew Faster for embrace than I do
You see, his heart is his alone; Why not my heart be all my own?
O heart, you see how he slights me Yet you clasp him as if friendly
You follow him at will Is it "
You won't sulk first and then submit Who will then consult you, my heart?
Frets to gain and fears loss in gain O my heart suffers ceaseless pain
My itching mind eats me anon As I muse on him all alone
I forget shame but not his thought In mean foolish mind I'm caught
My heart living in love of him Hails his glory ignoring blame
Who support a man in grief If lover's heart denies relief?
Let clouds their visits stay, and dearth Distresses all the sea-girt earth
Virtue seeks and peeps to see Self-controlled savant anger free
Why wonder if strangers disown When one's own heart is not his own?
Feign sulk
thirukuralapi.trans2: embrace him not so that We can see his distress a bit

thirukuralapi.trans: Sulking is the salt of love
thirukuralapi.trans2: but Too much of it spoils the taste Wife Addresses Husband

thirukuralapi.trans: To leave the sulker unembraced Is to grieve the one sorely grieved
To comfort not lady in pout Is to cut the fading plant at root He within Himself
Pouting of flower-eyed has To pure good mates a lovely grace
Love devoid of frowns and pets Misses its ripe and unripe fruits
What's the good of grieving lament When concious lover is not present?
Water delights in a shady grove And sulking in souls of psychic love
Decorum does one dignity More than life guard its purity
My heart athirst would still unite With her who me in sulking left!
I shrink to clasp you bosom lewd To the gaze of all ladies exposed
He sneezed while we went on sulking Expecting me to say "

thirukuralapi.trans2: than whom?\"" she sulked and chid"

thirukuralapi.trans: I said I thought of you She left Her embrace crying "
I sneezed; she blessed; then changed and wept "
I repressed sneeze; she wept crying "
I try to coax her and she remarks "
Virtues of conduct all excel
thirukuralapi.trans2: The soul aid should be guarded well

thirukuralapi.trans: I think and gaze at her; she chides: "
He is flawless
thirukuralapi.trans2: but I do pout So that his loving ways show out

thirukuralapi.trans: Fading first, love blooms and outlives The petty pricks that pouting gives
Is there a heaven like sulk beneath Of hearts that join like water and earth?
In long pout after embrace sweet A weapon is up to break my heart
Though free form faults, one feels the charms Of feigned release from lover's arms
Sweeter than meal is digestion And sulk in love than union
The yielder wins in lover's pout Reunited joy brings it out
Shall not our pouting again give The dew-browed joy of joint love?
Sulk on O belle of shining jewels! Prolong O night! our delight swells!
Good conduct shows good family Low manners mark anomaly
Bouderie is lovers' delight Its delight grows when they unite
Readers recall forgotten lore, But conduct lost returns no more
The envious prosper but ill The ill-behaved sinks lower still
The firm from virtue falter not They know the ills of evil thought
Conduct good ennobles man, Bad conduct entails disgrace mean
Good conduct sows seeds of blessings Bad conduct endless evil brings
Foul words will never fall from lips Of righteous men even by slips
Unless the fruitful shower descend, The ploughman's sacred toil must end
Though read much they are ignorant Whose life is not world-accordant
Who know the wealth and virtue's way After other's wife do not stray
He is the worst law breaking boor Who haunts around his neighbour's door
The vile are dead who evil aim And put faithful friends' wives to shame
Their boasted greatness means nothing When to another's wife they cling
Who trifles with another's wife His guilty stain will last for life
Hatred, sin, fear, and shame-these four Stain adulterers ever more
He is the righteous householder His neighbour's wife who covets never
They lead a high-souled manly life The pure who eye not another's wife
Good in storm bound earth is with those Who clasp not arms of another's spouse
Destruction it may sometimes pour But only rain can life restore
Sinners breaking virtue's behest Lust not for another's wife at least
As earth bears up with diggers too To bear revilers is prime virtue
Forgive insults is a good habit Better it is to forget it
Neglect the guest is dearth of dearth To bear with fools is strength of strength
Practice of patient quality Retains intact itegrity
Vengeance is not in esteem held Patience is praised as hidden gold
Revenge accords but one day's joy Patience carries its praise for aye
Though others cause you wanton pain Grieve not
thirukuralapi.trans2: from unjust harm refrain

thirukuralapi.trans: By noble forbearance vanquish The proud that have caused you anguish
More than ascetics they are pure Who bitter tongues meekly endure
No grassy blade its head will rear, If from the cloud no drop appear
Who fast are great to do penance Greater are they who bear offence
Deem your heart as virtuous When your nature is not jealous
No excellence excels the one That by nature envies none
Who envies others' good fortune Can't prosper in virtue of his own
The wise through envy don't others wrong Knowing that woes from evils throng
Man shall be wrecked by envy's whim Even if enemies spare him
Who envies gifts shall suffer ruin Without food and clothes with his kin
Fortune deserts the envious Leaving misfortune omnious
Caitiff envy despoils wealth And drags one into evil path
Why is envy rich, goodmen poor People with surprise think over
The ocean's wealth will waste away, Except the cloud its stores repay
The envious prosper never The envyless prosper ever
Who covets others' honest wealth That greed ruins his house forthwith
Who shrink with shame from sin, refrain From coveting which brings ruin
For spiritual bliss who long For fleeting joy commit no wrong
The truth-knowers of sense-control Though in want covet not at all
What is one's subtle wisdom worth If it deals ill with all on earth
Who seeks for grace on righteous path Suffers by evil covetous wealth
Shun the fruit of covetousness All its yield is inglorious
The mark of lasting wealth is shown By not coveting others' own
Fortune seeks the just and wise Who are free from coveting vice
The earth, beneath a barren sky, Would offerings for the gods deny
Desireless, greatness conquers all; Coveting misers ruined fall
Though a man from virtue strays, To keep from slander brings him praise
Who bite behind, and before smile Are worse than open traitors vile
Virtue thinks it better to die, Than live to backbite and to lie
Though harsh you speak in one's presence Abuse is worse in his absence
Who turns to slander makes it plain His praise of virtue is in vain
His failings will be found and shown, Who makes another's failings known
By pleasing words who make not friends Sever their hearts by hostile trends
What will they not to strangers do Who bring their friends' defects to view?
The world in mercy bears his load Who rants behind words untoward
Were heaven above to fail below Nor alms nor penance earth would show
No harm would fall to any man If each his own defect could scan
With silly words who insults all Is held in contempt as banal
Vain talk before many is worse Than doing to friends deeds adverse
The babbler's hasty lips proclaim That "
Vain words before an assembly Will make all gains and goodness flee
Glory and grace will go away When savants silly nonsense say
Call him a human chaff who prides Himself in weightless idle words
Let not men of worth vainly quack Even if they would roughly speak
The wise who weigh the worth refrain From words that have no grain and brain
The wise of spotless self-vision Slip not to silly words-mention
That lore is vain which does not fall At His good feet who knoweth all
Water is life that comes from rain Sans rain our duties go in vain
To purpose speak the fruitful word And never indulge in useless load
Sinners fear not the pride of sin The worthy dread the ill within
Since evil begets evil dire Fear ye evil more than fire
The wisest of the wise are those Who injure not even their foes
His ruin virtue plots who plans The ruin of another man's
Who makes poverty plea for ill Shall reduce himself poorer still
From wounding others let him refrain Who would from harm himself remain
Men may escape other foes and live But sin its deadly blow will give
Ruin follows who evil do As shadow follows as they go
Let none who loves himself at all Think of evil however small
No merit can be held so high As theirs who sense and self deny
He is secure, know ye, from ills Who slips not right path to do evils
Duty demands nothing in turn
thirukuralapi.trans2: How can the world recompense rain?

thirukuralapi.trans: All the wealth that toils give Is meant to serve those who deserve
In heav'n and earth 'tis hard to find A greater good than being kind
He lives who knows befitting act Others are deemed as dead in fact
The wealth that wise and kind do make Is like water that fills a lake
Who plenty gets and plenty gives Is like town-tree teeming with fruits
The wealth of a wide-hearted soul Is a herbal tree that healeth all
Though seers may fall on evil days Their sense of duty never strays
The good man's poverty and grief Is want of means to give relief
To con ascetic glory here Is to count the dead upon the sphere
By good if ruin comes across Sell yourself to save that loss
To give the poor is charity The rest is loan and vanity
To beg is bad e'en from the good To give is good, were heaven forbid
No pleading, "
thirukuralapi.trans2: \"" But giving marks a noble birth"

thirukuralapi.trans: The cry for alms is painful sight Until the giver sees him bright
Higher's power which hunger cures Than that of penance which endures
Drive from the poor their gnawing pains If room you seek to store your gains
Who shares his food with those who need Hunger shall not harm his creed
The joy of give and take they lose Hard-hearted rich whose hoarding fails
Worse than begging is that boarding Alone what one's greed is hoarding
No lustre can with theirs compare Who know the right and virtue wear
Nothing is more painful than death Yet more is pain of giftless dearth
They gather fame who freely give The greatest gain for all that live
The glory of the alms-giver Is praised aloud as popular
Nothing else lasts on earth for e'er Saving high fame of the giver!
From hailing gods heavens will cease To hail the men of lasting praise
Fame in fall and life in death Are rare but for the soulful worth
Be born with fame if birth you want If not of birth you must not vaunt
Why grieve at those who blame the shame Of those who cannot live in fame?
To men on earth it is a shame Not to beget the child of fame
The land will shrink in yield if men O'erburden it without renown
With hook of firmness to restrain The senses five, is heaven to gain
They live who live without blemish The blameful ones do not flurish
The wealth of wealth is wealth of grace Earthly wealth e'en the basest has
Seek by sound ways good compassion
thirukuralapi.trans2: All faiths mark that for-salvation

thirukuralapi.trans: The hearts of mercy shall not go Into dark worlds of gruesome woe
His soul is free from dread of sins Whose mercy serveth all beings
The wide wind-fed world witness bears: Men of mercy meet not sorrows
Who grace forsake and graceless act The former loss and woes forget
This world is not for weathless ones That world is not for graceless swines
The wealthless may prosper one day
thirukuralapi.trans2: The graceless never bloom agay

thirukuralapi.trans: Like Truth twisted by confused mind Wisdom is vain in hearts unkind
Indra himself has cause to say How great the power ascetics' sway
Think how you feel before the strong When to the feeble you do wrong
What graciousness can one command who feeds his flesh by flesh gourmand
The thriftless have no property And flesh-eaters have no pity
Who wields a steel is steel-hearted Who tastes body is hard-hearted
If merciless it is to kill, To kill and eat is disgraceful
Off with flesh
thirukuralapi.trans2: a life you save The eater hell's mouth shall not waive!

thirukuralapi.trans: None would kill and sell the flesh For eating it if they don't wish
From eating flesh men must abstain If they but feel the being's pain
Whose mind from illusion is freed Refuse on lifeless flesh to feed
Not to-kill-and-eat, truly Excels thousand pourings of ghee!
The small the paths of ease pursue The great achieve things rare to do
All lives shall lift their palms to him Who eats not flesh nor kills with whim
Pains endure
thirukuralapi.trans2: pain not beings This is the type of true penance

thirukuralapi.trans: Penance is fit for penitents Not for him who in vain pretends
Is it to true penitent's aid, That others austere path avoid?
In penance lies the power to save The friends and foil the foe and knave
What they wish as they wish is won Here hence by men penance is done
Who do penance achieve their aim Others desire-rid themselves harm
Pure and bright gets the gold in fire
thirukuralapi.trans2: and so the life by pain austere

thirukuralapi.trans: He worship wins from every soul Who Master is by soul control
They can even defy death Who get by penance godly strenth
They gain the world, who grasp and tell Of taste, sight, hearing, touch and smell
Many are poor and few are rich For they care not for penance much
Elements five of feigned life Of a sly hypocrite within laugh
Of what avail are sky-high shows When guild the conscience gnaws and knows
Vaunting sainthood while week within Seems a grazer with tiger skin
Sinning in saintly show is like Fowlers in ambush birds to strike
Who false within but freedom feign Shall moan "
Vilest is he who seems a saint Cheating the world without restraint
Berry-red is his outward view, Black like its nose his inward hue
Filthy in mind some bathe in streams Hiding sins in showy extremes
Know men by acts and not by forms Strait arrow kills, bent lute but charms
Full-worded men by what they say, Their greatness to the world display
No balding nor tangling the hair! Abstain from condemned acts with care
Let him who would reproachless be From all frauds guard his conscience free
The gain by fraud may overflow But swift to ruin it shall go
The fruit that fraud and greed obtain Shall end in endless grief and pain
Love and Grace are not their worth Who watch to waylay dozer's wealth
They cannot walk in measured bounds who crave and have covetous ends
Men of measured wisdom shun Black art of fraud and what it won
Virtue abides in righteous hearts Into minds of frauds deceit darts
They perish in their perfidy Who know nothing but pilfery
Their wrath, who've climb'd the mount of good, Though transient, cannot be withstood
Even the body rejects thieves; The honest men, heaven receives
If "
thirukuralapi.trans2: It is to speak out evil-free"

thirukuralapi.trans: E'en falsehood may for truth suffice, When good it brings removing vice
Let not a man knowingly lie
thirukuralapi.trans2: Conscience will scorch and make him sigh

thirukuralapi.trans: He lives in loving hearts of all Who serves the Truth serene in soul
To speak the truth from heart sincere Is more than giving and living austere
Not to lie brings all the praise All virtues from Truth arise
Lie not lie not Naught else you need All virtues are in Truth indeed
Water makes you pure outward Truth renders you pure inward
All lights are not lights for the wise
thirukuralapi.trans2: Truth light is light bright like Sun-light

thirukuralapi.trans: Long they live on earth who gain The feet of God in florid brain
With gentle mercy towards all, The sage fulfils the vitue's call
Of all the things we here have seen Nothing surpasses Truth serene!
Anger against the weak is wrong It is futile against the strong
Vain is wrath against men of force Against the meek it is still worse
Off with wrath with any one It is the source of sin and pain
Is there a foe like harmful ire Which kills the smile and joyful cheer?
Thyself to save, from wrath away! If not thyself the wrath will slay
Friend-killer is the fatal rage It burns the helpful kinship-barge
The wrath-lover to doom is bound Like failless-hand that strikes the ground
Save thy soul from burning ire Though tortured like the touch of fire
Wishes he gains as he wishes If man refrains from rage vicious!
From virtue weal and wealth outflow
thirukuralapi.trans2: What greater good can mankind know?

thirukuralapi.trans: Dead are they who are anger-fed Saints are they from whom wrath has fled
The pure by faith mean pain to none Though princely wealth by that is won
The spotless hearts seek not revenge Though Malice does the worst in rage
Revenging even causeless hate Bad-blood breeds and baneful heat
Doing good-turns, put them to shame Thus chide the evil who do harm
What does a man from wisdom gain If he pines not at other's pain?
What you feel as pain to yourself Do it not to the other-self
Any, anywhere injure not At any time even in thought
How can he injure other souls Who in his life injury feels
Harm others in the forenoon Harm seeks thee in afternoon
Virtue enhances joy and gain
thirukuralapi.trans2: Forsaking it is fall and pain

thirukuralapi.trans: No harm is done by peace-lovers For pains rebound on pain-givers
What is Virtue? 'Tis not to kill For killing causes every ill
Share the food and serve all lives This is the law of all the laws
Not to kill is unique good The next, not to utter falsehood
What way is good? That we can say The way away from heat to slay
Of saints who renounce birth-fearing The head is he who dreads killing
Life-eating-Death shall spare the breath Of him who no life puts to death
Kill not life that others cherish Even when your life must perish
The gain of slaughter is a vice Though deemed good in sacrifice
Those who live by slaying are Eaters of carrion bizarre!
Perform good deeds as much you can Always and everywhere, o man!

thirukuralapi.line1: உயிர் உடம்பின் நீக்கியார் என்ப செயிர் உடம்பின்
thirukuralapi.trans: The loathsome poor sickly and sore Are killers stained by blood before
The worst of follies it is told The fleeting as lasting to hold
Like a drama-crowd wealth gathers Like passing show its pride too goes
Wealth wanes away
thirukuralapi.trans2: but when it comes Take care to do enduring things

thirukuralapi.trans: The showy day is but a saw Your life, know that, to file and gnaw
Ere tongue benumbs and hiccough comes Rise up to do good deeds betimes
One was yesterday
thirukuralapi.trans2: not today!

thirukuralapi.trans: Man knows not his next moment On crores of things he is intent
The soul from body any day Like bird from egg-shell flies away
Death is like a slumber deep And birth like waking from that sleep
In spotless mind virtue is found And not in show and swelling sound
The life berthed in this body shows A fixed home it never knows
From what from what a man is free From that, from that his torments flee
Give up all to gain the True And endless joys shall hence seek you
Curb the senses five and renounce The carving desires all at once
To have nothing is law of vows Having the least deludes and snares
Why add to bonds while this body Is too much for saints to be birth-free

thirukuralapi.line1: யான் எனது என்னும் செருக்கு அறுப்பான் வானோர்க்கு
thirukuralapi.trans: Who curbs the pride of I and mine Gets a world rare for gods to gain
Grief clings on and on to those Who cling to bonds without release
Who renounce all are free from care Others suffer delusive snare
Bondage cut off, rebirth is off The world then seems instable stuff
Four ills eschew and virtue reach, Lust, anger, envy, evil-speech
Bind Thyself to the unbound one That binding breaks all bonds anon
That error entails ignoble birth Which deems vain things as things of worth
Men of spotless pure insight Enjoy delight devoid of night
To doubtless minds whose heart is clear More than earth heaven is near
Knowledge of five senses is vain Without knowing the Truth within
Knowledge is truth of things to find In every case of every kind
Who learn and here the Truth discern Enter the path of non-return
One-minded sage sees inner-truth He is free from thoughts of rebirth
It is knowledge to know Self-Truth And remove the folly of birth
Know the Refuge; off with bondage Be free from ills of thraldom, O sage
Do good enow
thirukuralapi.trans2: defer it not A deathless aid in death if sought

thirukuralapi.trans: Woes expire when lust, wrath, folly Expire even to name, fully
Desire to all, always is seed From which ceaseless births proceed
If long thou must, long for non-birth It comes by longing no more for earth
No such wealth is here and there As peerless wealth of non-desire
To nothing crave is purity That is the fruit of verity
The free are those who desire not The rest not free in bonds are caught
Dread desire
thirukuralapi.trans2: Virtue is there To every soul desire is snare!

thirukuralapi.trans: Destroy desire
thirukuralapi.trans2: deliverance Comes as much as you aspire hence

thirukuralapi.trans: Desire extinct no sorrow-taints Grief comes on grief where it pretends
Desire, the woe of woes destroy Joy of joys here you enjoy
Litter-bearer and rider say Without a word, the fortune's way
Off with desire insatiate You gain the native blissful state
Efforts succeed by waxing star Wealth-losing brings waning star
Loss-fate makes a dull fool of us Gain-fate makes us prosperous, wise!
What matters subtle study deep? Levels of innate wisdom-keep
Two natures in the world obtain Some wealth and others wisdom gain
In making wealth fate changes mood
thirukuralapi.trans2: The good as bad and bad as good

thirukuralapi.trans: Things not thine never remain Things destined are surely thine
Who crores amass enjoy but what The Dispenser's decrees allot
The destitute desire will quit If fate with ills visit them not
Who good in time of good perceive In evil time why should they grieve?
Like stones that block rebirth and pain Are doing good and good again
What power surpasses fate? Its will Persists against the human skill
People, troops, wealth, forts, council, friends Who owns these six is lion of kings
Courage, giving, knowledge and zeal Are four failless features royal
Alertness, learning bravery Are adjuncts three of monarchy
A brave noble king refrains from vice Full of virtue and enterprise
The able king gets, stores and guards And spends them for people's safeguards
That land prospers where the king is Easy to see, not harsh of words
The world commends and acts his phrase Who sweetly speaks and gives with grace
He is the Lord of men who does Sound justice and saves his race
Under his shelter thrives the world Who bears remarks bitter and bold
Weal flows only from virtue done The rest is rue and renown gone
He is the Light of Kings who has Bounty, justice, care and grace
Lore worth learning, learn flawlessly Live by that learning thoroughly
Letter, number, art and science Of living kind both are the eyes
The learned alone have eyes on face The ignorant two sores of disgrace
To meet with joy and part with thought Of learned men this is the art
Like poor before rich they yearn: For knowledge: the low never learn
As deep you dig the sand spring flows As deep you learn the knowledge grows
All lands and towns are learner's own Why not till death learning go on!
The joy of learning in one birth Exalts man upto his seventh
The learned foster learning more On seeing the world enjoy their lore
Who hold His feet who likes nor loathes Are free from woes of human births
Worthy act is virtue done Vice is what we ought to shun
Learning is wealth none could destroy Nothing else gives genuine joy
Like play of chess on squareless board Vain is imperfect loreless word
Unlearned man aspiring speech Is breastless lady's love-approach
Ev'n unread men are good and wise If before the wise, they hold their peace
The unread's wit though excellent Is not valued by the savant
A man untaught when speech he vaunts Sadly fails before savants
People speak of untaught minds "
Like painted clay-doll is his show Grand subtle lore who fails to know
Wealth in the hand of fools is worse Than a learned man's empty purse
Lower are fools of higher birth Than low-born men of learning's worth
The ideal householder is he Who aids the natural orders there
Like beasts before men, dunces are Before scholars of shining lore
Wealth of wealths is listening's wealth It is the best of wealths on earth
Some food for the stomach is brought When the ear gets no food for thought
Whose ears get lots of wisdom-food Equal gods on oblations fed
Though not learned, hear and heed That serves a staff and stay in need
Virtuous men's wisdom is found A strong staff on slippery ground
Lend ear to good words however few That much will highly exalt you
Who listen well and learn sharply Not ev'n by slip speak foolishly
That ear though hearing is dulled Which is not by wisdom drilled
A modest mouth is hard for those Who care little to counsels wise
His help the monk and retired share, And celibate students are his care
Who taste by mouth and not by ear What if they fare ill or well here?
Wisdom's weapon wards off all woes It is a fort defying foes
Wisdom checks the straying senses Expels evils, impels goodness
To grasp the Truth from everywhere From everyone is wisdom fair
Speaking out thoughts in clear trends Wisdom subtle sense comprehends
The wise-world the wise befriend They bloom nor gloom, equal in mind
As moves the world so move the wise In tune with changing times and ways
The wise foresee what is to come The unwise lack in that wisdom
Fear the frightful and act wisely Not to fear the frightful's folly
No frightful evil shocks the wise Who guard themselves against surprise
By dutiful householder's aid God, manes, kin, self and guests are served
Who have wisdom they are all full Whatev'r they own, misfits are nil
Plenty is their prosperity Who're free from wrath pride lust petty
Mean pride, low pleasure, avarice These add blemishes to a prince
Though millet-small their faults might seem Men fearing disgrace, Palm-tall deem
Watch like treasure freedom from fault Our fatal foe is that default
Who fails to guard himself from flaw Loses his life like flame-lit straw
What fault can be the king's who cures First his faults, then scans others
That miser's wealth shall waste and end Who would not for a good cause spend
The gripping greed of miser's heart Is more than fault the worst apart
Never boast yourself in any mood Nor do a deed that does no good
Sin he shuns and food he shares His home is bright and brighter fares
All designs of the foes shall fail If one his wishes guards in veil
Weigh their worth and friendship gain Of men of virtue and mature brain
Cherish the help of men of skill Who ward and safe-guard you from ill
Honour and have the great your own Is rarest of the rare things known
To have betters as intimates Power of all powers promotes
Ministers are the monarch's eyes Round him should be the right and wise
To move with worthy friends who knows Has none to fear from frightful foes
No foe can foil his powers whose friends reprove him when he errs
The careless king whom none reproves Ruins himself sans harmful foes
No capital, no gain in trade No prop secure sans good comrade
In grace and gain the home excels, Where love with virtue sweetly dwells
To give up good friends is ten times worse Than being hated by countless foes
The ignoble the noble fear The mean hold them as kinsmen dear
With soil changes water's taste With mates changes the mental state
Wisdom depends upon the mind The worth of man upon his friend
Wisdom seems to come from mind But it truly flows from the kind
Purity of the thought and deed Comes from good company indeed
Pure-hearted get good progeny Pure friendship acts with victory
Goodness of mind increases gain Good friendship fosters fame again
Men of wisdom, though good in mind In friends of worth a new strength find
Good mind decides the future bliss Good company gains strength to this
Who turns from righteous family To be a monk, what profits he?
No help good company exeeds
thirukuralapi.trans2: The bad to untold anguish leads

thirukuralapi.trans: Weigh well output the loss and gain And proper action ascertain
Nothing is hard for him who acts With worthy counsels weighing facts
The wise risk not their capital In doubtful gains and lose their all
They who scornful reproach fear Commence no work not made clear
Who marches without plans and ways His field is sure to foster foes
Doing unfit action ruins Failing fit-act also ruins
Think and dare a proper deed Dare and think is bad in need
Toil without a plan ahead Is doomed to fall though supported
Attune the deeds to habitude Or ev'n good leads to evil feud
Of all who strive for bliss, the great Is he who leads the married state
Do deeds above reproachfulness The world refutes uncomely mess
Judge act and might and foeman's strength The allies' strength and go at length
Nothing hampers the firm who know What they can and how to go
Many know not their meagre might Their pride breaks up in boastful fight
Who adapts not, outsteps measure And brags himself-his fall is sure
Even the gentle peacock's plume Cart's axle breaks by gross volume
Beyond the branches' tip who skips Ends the life as his body rips
Know the limit
thirukuralapi.trans2: grant with measure This way give and guard your treasure

thirukuralapi.trans: The outflow must not be excess No matter how small income is
Who does not know to live in bounds His life seems rich but thins and ends
Straight in virtue, right in living Make men brighter than monks praying
Wealth amassed quickly vanishes Sans level if one lavishes
By day the crow defeats the owl Kings need right time their foes to quell
Well-ordered seasoned act is cord That fortune binds in bon accord
What is hard for him who acts With proper means and time and tacts?
Choose proper time and act and place Even the world you win with ease
Who want to win the world sublime Wait unruffled biding their time
By self-restraint stalwarts keep fit Like rams retreating but to butt
The wise jut not their vital fire They watch their time with hidden ire
Bear with hostiles when you meet them Fell down their head in fateful time
When comes the season ripe and rare Dare and do hard things then and there
Home-life and virtue, are the same; Which spotless monkhood too can claim
In waiting time feign peace like stork In fighting time strike like its peck
No action take, no foe despise Until you have surveyed the place
Many are gains of fortresses Ev'n to kings of power and prowess
Weaklings too withstand foe's offence In proper fields of strong defence
If fighters fight in vantage field The plans of foes shall be baffled
In water crocodile prevails In land before others it fails
Sea-going ship goes not on shore Nor on sea the strong-wheeled car
No aid but daring dash they need When field is chosen right for deed
Though force is small, if place is right One quells a foe of well-armed might
To face a foe at home is vain Though fort and status are not fine
God's praise who tell, are free from right And wrong, the twins of dreaming night
He is a man of divine worth Who lives in ideal home on earth
A fox can kill a war tusker Fearless with feet in deep quagmire
Pleasure, gold, fear of life Virtue- Test by these four and trust the true
Spotless name of noble birth Shamed of stain-that choice is worth
Though deep scholars of stainless sense Rare is freedom from ignorance
Good and evil in man weigh well Judge him by virtues which prevail
By the touchstone of deeds is seen If any one is great or mean
Choose not those men without kinsmen Without affine or shame of sin
On favour leaning fools you choose
thirukuralapi.trans2: Folly in all its forms ensues

thirukuralapi.trans: To trust an untried stranger brings Endless troubles on all our kins
Trust not without testing and then Find proper work for trusted men
A good housewife befits the house, Spending with thrift the mate's resource
Trust without test
thirukuralapi.trans2: The trusted doubt

thirukuralapi.trans: Employ the wise who will discern The good and bad and do good turn
Let him act who resource swells
thirukuralapi.trans2: Fosters wealth and prevents ills

thirukuralapi.trans: Trust him in whom these four you see: Love, wit, non-craving, clarity
Though tried and found fit, yet we see Many differ before duty
Wise able men with power invest Not by fondness but by hard test
Discern the agent and the deed And just in proper time proceed
This work, by this, this man can do Like this entrust the duty due
His fitness for the duty scan Leave him to do the best he can
Who do duty for duty's sake Doubt them
thirukuralapi.trans2: and fortune departs quick

thirukuralapi.trans: Bright is home when wife is chaste If not all greatness is but waste
Worker straight the world is straight The king must look to this aright
Let fortunes go
thirukuralapi.trans2: yet kinsmen know The old accustomed love to show

thirukuralapi.trans: The gift of loving Kins bestows Fadeless fortune's fresh flowers
A kinless wealth is like a tank Which overflows without a bank
The fruit of growing wealth is gained When kith and kin are happy found
Loving words and liberal hand Encircle kith and kin around
Large giver and wrathless man Commands on earth countless kinsmen
The crows hide not
thirukuralapi.trans2: thy call and eat Welfare abides a man of heart

thirukuralapi.trans: From public gaze when kings perceive Each one's merits so many thrive
Forsaken friends will come and stay When cause for discord goes away
What is rare when wife is good What can be there when she is bad?
Who leaves and returns with motive The king should test him and receive
Worse than wrath in excess is Forgetfulness in joy-excess
Negligence kills renown just as Ceaseless want wisdom destroys
Forgetful nature fails of fame All schools of thinkers say the same
The fearful find no fortress here The forgetful find good never
Failing foresight the guardless man Shall rue his folly later on
Forget none
thirukuralapi.trans2: watch with wakeful care Miss none

thirukuralapi.trans: With cautious care pursue a thing Impossible there is nothing
Do what the wise commend as worth If not, for seven births no mirth
When joy deludes, their fate recall Whom negligence has made to fall
What greater fortune is for men Than a constant chaste woman?
Easy it is a thing to get When the mind on it is set
Test and attest impartially Consult and act the laws justly
The earth looks up to sky and thrives And mankind to king's rod of justice
The Sage's scripture and virtue spring From the sceptre of a stately king
The world clings to the ruler's feet Whose sceptre clasps the people's heart
Full rains and yields enrich the land Which is ruled by a righteous hand
Not the spear but the sceptre straight That brings success to monarch's might
The king protects the entire earth And justice protects his royal worth
Hard of access, the unjust king He shall himself his ruin bring
Save his subjects and chide the wrong Is flawless duty of a king
Her spouse before God who adores, Is like rain that at request pours
Killing killers, the king, behold Weeds removes from cropful field
The unjust tyrant oppressor Is worse than cruel murderer
Sceptered tyrant exacting gold Is "
Spy wrongs daily and do justice Or day by day the realm decays
The king shall wealth and subjects lose If his sceptre he dares abuse
Groaning tears caused by tyrant's sway File the royal wealth away
Glory endures by sceptre right Without it wanes the royal light
Dry like the earth without rainfall Is graceless king to creatures all
To have is worse than having not If ruler is unjust despot
The sky withdraws season's shower If the king misuses his power
The good wife guards herself from blame, She tends her spouse and brings him fame

The *six-functioned forget their lore Cows give less if kings guard no more * the six functions are: learning, teaching, giving, getting, sacrificing, kindling sacrifice These are duties of Vedic savants
A king enquires and gives sentence Just to prevent future offence
Wield fast the rod but gently lay This strict mildness prolongs the sway
His cruel rod of dreadful deed Brings king's ruin quick indeed
As men the king a tyrant call His days dwindled, hasten his fall
Whose sight is scarce, whose face is foul His wealth seems watched by a ghoul
Whose word is harsh, whose sight is rude His wealth and power quickly fade
Reproofs rough and punishments rude Like files conquering power corrode
The king who would not take counsels Rages with wrath-his fortune fails
The king who builds not fort betimes Fears his foes in wars and dies
Of what avail are watch and ward? Their purity is women's guard
The crushing burden borne by earth Is tyrants bound to fools uncouth
Living in the world implies The bounteous dame of benign eyes
World lives by looks of lovely worth Who lack them are burdens of earth
Of tuneless song what is the use? Without gracious looks what are eyes?
Except that they are on the face What for are eyes sans measured grace
Kind looks are jewels for eyes to wear Without them they are felt as sore
Like trees on inert earth they grow Who don't eye to eye kindness show
Ungracious men lack real eyes Men of real eyes show benign grace
Who gracious are but dutiful Have right for this earth beautiful
To be benign and bear with foes Who vex us is true virtue's phase
Women who win their husbands' heart Shall flourish where the gods resort
Men of graceful courtesy Take hemlock and look cheerfully
A king should treat these two as eyes The code of laws and careful spies
All that happens, always, to all The king should know in full detail
Conquests are not for the monarch Who cares not for the Spy's remark
His officers, kinsmen and foes Who watch keenly are worthy spies
Fearless gaze, suspectless guise Guarding secrets mark the spies
Guised as monks they gather secrets They betray them not under threats
A spy draws out other's secrets Beyond a doubt he clears his facts
The reports given by one spy By another spy verify
Engage the spies alone, apart When three agree confirm report
A cuckold has not the lion-like gait Before his detractors aright
Give not the spy open reward It would divulge the secret heard!
To own is to own energy All others own but lethargy
Psychic heart is wealth indeed Worldly wealth departs in speed
The strong in will do not complain The loss of worldly wealth and gain
Fortune enquires, enters with boom Where tireless strivers have their home
Water depth is lotus height Mental strength is men's merit
Let thoughts be always great and grand Though they fail their virtues stand
Elephants are firm when arrows hit Great minds keep fit ev'n in defeat
Heartless persons cannot boast "
Huge elephant sharp in tusk quails When tiger, less in form, assails
They prosper long who walk His way Who has the senses signed away
An honest wife is home's delight And children good are jewels abright
Mental courage is true manhood Lacking that man is like a wood
Quenchless lamp of ancestry goes When foul idleness encloses
To make your home an ideal home Loath sloth as sloth
thirukuralapi.trans2: refuse it room

thirukuralapi.trans: The fool who fosters sluggishness Before he dies ruins his house
Who strive not high, sunk deep in sloth Ruin their house by evil growth
To lag, forget, idle and doze These four are pleasure boats of loss
With all the wealth of lords of earth The slothful gain nothing of worth
The slothful lacking noble deeds Subject themselves to scornful words
If sloth invades a noble house It will become a slave of foes
The blots on race and rule shall cease When one from sloth gets his release
The world no higher bliss bestows Than children virtuous and wise
The slothless king shall gain en masse *All regions trod by Lord apace * Hindu mythology holds that Lord Vishnu measured with his feet the three worlds
Feel not frustrate saying This hard Who tries attains striving's reward
In doing work don't break and shirk The world will quit who quits his work
On excellence of industry Depends magnanimous bounty
Bounty of man who never strives Like sword in eunuch's hand it fails
Work who likes and not pleasure Wipes grief of friends, pillar secure
Industry adds prosperity Indolence brings but poverty
Illuck abides with sloth they say *Laxmi's gifts with labourers stay *Laxmi the Goddes of wealth and prosperity
Misfortune is disgrace to none The shame is nothing learnt or done
Though fate is against fulfilment Hard labour has ready payment
No evil comes and no blemish
thirukuralapi.trans2: Noble sons bring all we wish

thirukuralapi.trans: Tireless Toiler's striving hand Shall leave even the fate behind
Laugh away troubles
thirukuralapi.trans2: there is No other way to conquer woes

thirukuralapi.trans: Deluging sorrows come to nought When wise men face them with firm thought
Grief they face and put to grief Who grieve not grief by mind's relief
Who pulls like bulls patiently on Causes grief to grieve anon
Before the brave grief grieves and goes Who dare a host of pressing woes
The wise that never gloat in gain Do not fret in fateful ruin
The wise worry no more of woes Knowing body's butt of sorrows
Who seek not joy, deem grief norm By sorrows do not come to harm
In joy to joy who is not bound In grief he grieves not dual round!
Children are one's wealth indeed Their wealth is measured by their deed
His glory is esteemed by foes Who sees weal in wanton woes!
He is minister who chooses Right means, time, mode and rare ventures
With these he guards people, -by his Knowledge, firmness and manliness
A minister cherishes friends Divides foes and the parted blends
A minister must sift reflect Select and say surely one fact
Have him for help who virtue knows Right wisdom speaks, ever apt in acts
Which subtler brain can stand before The keen in brain with learned love?
Albeit you know to act from books Act after knowing world's outlooks
The man in place must tell the facts Though the ignorant king refutes
Seventy crores of foes are better Than a minister with mind bitter
The food is more than nectar sweet In which one's children hands insert
The unresolved, though well designed To fulfil an act they have no mind
The goodness called goodness of speech Is goodness which nothing can reach
Since gain or ruin speeches bring Guard against the slips of tongue
A speech is speech that holds ears And attracts ev'n those that are averse
Weigh thy words and speak
thirukuralapi.trans2: because No wealth or virtue words surpass

thirukuralapi.trans: Speak out thy world so that no word Can win it and say untoward
Spotless men speak what is sweet And grasp in others what is meet
No foe defies the speaker clear Flawless, puissant, and free from fear
The world will quickly carry out The words of counsellors astute
They overspeak who do not seek A few and flawless words to speak
Children's touch delights the body Sweet to ears are their words lovely
Who can't express what they have learnt Are bunch of flowers not fragrant
Friendship brings gain
thirukuralapi.trans2: but action pure Does every good thing we desire

thirukuralapi.trans: Eschew always acts that do not Bring good nor glory on their part
Those in the world desire for fame Should shun the deed that dims their name
Though perils press the faultless wise Shun deeds of mean, shameful device
Do not wrong act and grieve, "
thirukuralapi.trans2: do not repeat it twice"

thirukuralapi.trans: Though she who begot thee hungers Shun acts denounced by ancient seers
Pinching poverty of the wise Is more than wealth hoarded by Vice
Those who dare a forbidden deed Suffer troubles though they succeed
Gains from weeping, weeping go Though lost, from good deeds blessings flow
The flute and lute are sweet they say Deaf to baby's babble's lay!
The wealth gathered in guilty ways Is water poured in wet clay vase
A powerful mind does powerful act And all the rest are imperfect
Shun failing fuss
thirukuralapi.trans2: fail not purpose These two are maxims of the wise

thirukuralapi.trans: The strong achieve and then display Woe unto work displayed midway
Easy it is to tell a fact But hard it is to know and act
Dynamic deeds of a doughty soul Shall win the praise of king and all
The will-to-do achieves the deed When mind that wills is strong indeed
Scorn not the form: for men there are Like linchpin of big rolling car
Waver not
thirukuralapi.trans2: do wakefully The deed resolved purposefully

thirukuralapi.trans: Do with firm will though pains beset The deed that brings delight at last
A father's duty to his son is To seat him in front of the wise
The world merits no other strength But strength of will-to-do at length
When counsel takes a resolve strong Weak delay of action is wrong
Delay such acts as need delay Delay not acts that need display
It's best to act when feasible If not see what is possible
Work or foe left unfinished Flare up like fire unextinguished
Money and means, time, place and deed Decide these five and then proceed
Weigh well the end, hindrance, profit And then pursue a fitting act
Know first the secret from experts That is the way of fruitful acts
Lure a tusker by a tusker Achieve a deed by deed better
Than doing good to friends it is More urgent to befriend the foes
With joy the hearts of parents swell To see their children themselves excel
Small statesmen fearing people's fear Submit to foes superior
Love, noble birth, good courtesy Pleasing kings mark true embassy
Envoys must bear love for their prince Knowledge and learned eloquence
Savant among savants, he pleads Before lanced king, triumphant words
Who has these three: good form, sense, lore Can act as bold ambassador
Not harsh, the envoy's winsome ways Does good by pleasant words concise
Learned; fearless, the envoy tends Convincing words which time demands
Knowing duty time and place The envoy employs mature phrase
The true envoy of three virtues Is pure helpful and bold in views
The envoy who ports the king's message Has flawless words and heart's courage
The mother, hearing her son's merit Delights more than when she begot
Braving death the bold envoy Assures his king's safety and joy
Move with hostile kings as with fire Not coming close nor going far
Crave not for things which kings desire This brings thee their fruitful favour
Guard thyself from petty excess Suspected least, there's no redress
Whisper not
thirukuralapi.trans2: nor smile exchange Amidst august men's assemblage

thirukuralapi.trans: Hear not, ask not the king's secret Hear only when he lets it out
Discern his mood and time and tell No dislikes but what king likes well
Tell pleasing things
thirukuralapi.trans2: and never tell Even if pressed what is futile

thirukuralapi.trans: As young and kinsman do not slight
thirukuralapi.trans2: Look with awe king's light and might

thirukuralapi.trans: The clear-visioned do nothing base Deeming they have the monarch's grace
His feet, whose likeness none can find, Alone can ease the anxious mind
The son to sire this word is debt "
Worthless acts based on friendship old Shall spell ruin and woe untold
Who reads the mind by look, untold Adorns the changeless sea-girt world
Take him as God who reads the thought Of another man with without a doubt
By sign who scans the sign admit At any cost in cabinet
Untold, he who divines the thought Though same in form is quite apart
Among senses what for is eye If thought by thought one can't descry?
What throbs in mind the face reflects Just as mirror nearby objects
Than face what is subtler to tell First if the mind feels well or ill
Just standing in front would suffice For those who read the mind on face
Friend or foe the eyes will show To those who changing outlooks know
What bolt can bar true love in fact The tricking tears reveal the heart
The scale of keen discerning minds Is eye and eye that secrets finds
The pure in thought and eloquence Adapt their words to audience
Who know the art of speech shall suit Their chosen words to time in fact
They speak in vain at length who talk Words unversed which ears don't take
Before the bright be brilliant light Before the muff be mortar white
Modest restraint all good excels Which argues not before elders
Tongue-slip before the talented wise is like slipping from righteous ways
The learning of the learned shines Valued by flawless scholar-minds
To address understanding ones Is to water beds of growing grains
O ye who speak before the keen Forgetful, address not the mean
To selves belong the loveless ones
thirukuralapi.trans2: To oth'rs the loving e'en to bones

thirukuralapi.trans: To hostiles who wise words utters Pours ambrosia into gutters
The pure fail not in power of words Knowing grand council's moods and modes
Among scholars he is scholar Who holds scholars with learned lore
Many brave foes and die in fields The fearless few face wise councils
Impress the learned with your lore From greater savants learn still more
Grammar and logic learn so that Foes you can boldly retort
To cowards what can sword avail And books to those who councils fail?
Like eunuch's sword in field, is vain His lore who fears men of brain
Though learned much his lore is dead Who says no good before the good
Who fear to face good assembly Are learned idiots, certainly
Soul is encased in frame of bone To taste the life of love alone
They are breathing dead who dare not Empress before the wise their art
It's country which has souls of worth Unfailing yields and ample wealth
The Land has large luring treasure Where pests are nil and yields are sure
It's land that bears pressing burdens And pays its tax which king demands
It is country which is free from Fierce famine, plague and foemen's harm
Sects and ruinous foes are nil No traitors in a land tranquil
The land of lands no ruin knows Even in grief its wealth yet grows
Waters up and down, hills and streams With strong forts as limbs country beams
Rich yield, delight, defence and wealth Are jewels of lands with blooming health
A land is land which yields unsought Needing hard work the land is nought
Love yields aspiration and thence Friendship springs up in excellence
Though a land has thus every thing It is worthless without a king
The fort is vital for offence Who fear the foes has its defence
A crystal fount, a space a mount Thick woods form a fort paramount
An ideal fort's so says science: High, broad, strong and hard for access
Ample in space, easy to hold The fort foils enemies bold
Impregnable with stores of food Cosy to live-That fort is good
A fort is full of stores and arms And brave heroes to meet alarms
Besieging foes a fort withstands Darts and mines of treacherous hands
A fort holds itself and defies The attacks of encircling foes
A fort it is that fells the foes And gains by deeds a name glorious
The crowning joy of home life flows From peaceful psychic love always
But a fort however grand Is nil if heroes do not stand
Naught exists that can, save wealth Make the worthless as men of worth
The have-nothing poor all despise The men of wealth all raise and praise
Waneless wealth is light that goes To every land and gloom removes
The blameless wealth from fairest means Brings good virtue and also bliss
Riches devoid of love and grace Off with it
thirukuralapi.trans2: it is disgrace!

thirukuralapi.trans: Escheats, derelicts; spoils of war Taxes duties are king's treasure
Grace the child of love is nourished By the wet-nurse of wealth cherished
Treasures in hand fulfil all things Like hill-tuskers the wars of kings
Make wealth
thirukuralapi.trans2: there is no sharper steel The insolence of foes to quell

thirukuralapi.trans: They have joy and virtue at hand Who acquire treasures abundant
The daring well-armed winning force Is king's treasure and main resource
Through shots and wounds brave heroes hold Quailing not in fall, the field
Sea-like ratfoes roar What if? They perish at a cobra's whiff
The army guards its genial flame Not crushed, routed nor marred in name
The real army with rallied force Resists even Death-God fierce
Manly army has merits four:- Stately-march, faith, honour, valour
Army sets on to face to foes Knowing how the trend of war goes
Army gains force by grand array Lacking in stay or dash in fray
Army shall win if it is free From weakness, aversion, poverty
Justice burns the loveless form Like solar blaze the boneless worm
With troops in large numbers on rolls Army can't march missing gen'rals
Stand not before my chief, O foes! Many who stood, in stones repose
To lift a lance that missed a tusker Is prouder than shaft that hit a hare
Valour is fight with fierce courage Mercy to the fallen is its edge
At the tusker he flings his lance One in body smiles another chance
When lances dart if heroes wink "
The brave shall deem the days as vain Which did not battle-wounds sustain
Their anklets aloud jingle their name Who sacrifice their life for fame
The king may chide, they pursue strife; They fear loss of glory; not life
Who will blame the heroes that lose Their lives in war to keep their vows?
Life bereft of love is gloom Can sapless tree in desert bloom?
Such a death shall be prayed for Which draws the the tears of the ruler
Like friendship what's so hard to gain? That guards one against acts villain?
Good friendship shines like waxing moon, The bad withers like waning moon
Like taste in books good friendship grows The more one moves the more he knows
Not to laugh is friendship made But to hit when faults exceed
No close living nor clasping grip Friendship's feeling heart's fellowship
Friendship is not more smile on face It is the smiling heart's embrace
From ruin friendship saves and shares The load of pain and right path shows
Friendship hastens help in mishaps Like hands picking up dress that slips
Friendship is enthroned on the strength That always helps with utmost warmth
Love is the heart which limbs must move, Or vain the outer parts will prove
Than testless friendship nought is worse For contacts formed will scarcely cease
Friendship made without frequent test Shall end in grief and death at last
Temper, descent, defects and kins Trace well and take companions
Take as good friend at any price The nobly born who shun disgrace
Who make you weep and chide wrong trends And lead you right are worthy friends
Is there a test like misfortune A rod to measure out kinsmen?
Keep off contacts with fools
thirukuralapi.trans2: that is The greatest gain so say the wise

thirukuralapi.trans: Off with thoughts that depress the heart Off with friends that in woe depart
Friends who betray at ruin's brink Burn our mind ev'n at death to think
Who swims the sea of vice is he Who clasps the feet of Virtue's sea
The seat of life is love alone
thirukuralapi.trans2: Or beings are but skin and bone!

thirukuralapi.trans: The blameless ones as friends embarace
thirukuralapi.trans2: Give something and give up the base

thirukuralapi.trans: That friendship is good amity Which restrains not one's liberty
Friendship's heart is freedom close
thirukuralapi.trans2: Wise men's duty is such to please

thirukuralapi.trans: Of long friendship what is the use Righteous freedom if men refuse?
Things done unasked by loving friends Please the wise as familiar trends!
Offence of friends feel it easy As folloy or close intimacy
They forsake not but continue In friendship's bounds though loss ensue
Comrades established in firm love Though ruin comes waive not their vow
Fast friends who list not tales of ill Though wronged they say "
To love such friends the world desires Whose friendship has unbroken ties
Men set up home, toil and earn To tend the guests and do good turn
Even foes love for better ends Those who leave not long-standing friends
Swallowing love of soulless men Had better wane than wax anon
Who fawn in wealth and fail in dearth Gain or lose
thirukuralapi.trans2: such friends have no worth

thirukuralapi.trans: Cunning friends who calculate Are like thieves and whores wicked
Better be alone than trust in those That throw in field like faithless horse
Friends low and mean that give no help- Leave them is better than to keep
Million times the wise man's hate Is better than a fool intimate
Ten-fold crore you gain from foes Than from friends who are vain laughers
Without a word those friends eschew Who spoil deeds which they can do
Even in dreams the tie is bad With those whose deed is far from word
To keep out guests cannot be good Albeit you eat nector-like food
Keep aloof from those that smile At home and in public revile
The friendship by an enemy shown Is anvil in time, to strike you down
Who pretend kinship but are not Their friendship's fickle like woman's heart
They may be vast in good studies But heartfelt-love is hard for foes
Fear foes whose face has winning smiles Whose heart is full of cunning guiles
Do not trust in what they tell Whose mind with your mind goes ill
The words of foes is quickly seen Though they speak like friends in fine
